title: Request to increase the number of files limit on Gilbreth's scratch
customernote: Some people who received this message don't often get email from . Learn why this is important<https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification> Hi RCAC, I'm name, from IDEAS lab. I'm training on a very big dataset that has about 20M files when I extract it from a zip file. I'm wondering if it is possible to increase the limit for the number of files on scratch directory from 2M to 20-30M? If not, is there any recommended approach to deal with this dataset? Any insight would be greatly appreciated. Thank you. Regards, name Hi name, Thanks for reaching out! I do not think we could increase the limit to 20M on Gilbreth. Since you are running training on Gilbreth, why not just keep these data into that zip file and not extract them into small pieces? We always recommend users who train data to use an aggregate file format, like tar, zip, sqlite. In this way, it won't produce tons of small files. Cheers, --- name, PhD Sr. Computational Scientist RCAC Research Computing Purdue University  Hi name, The reason why I didn't work directly with the tar.gz file was because it's very big (1.5TB). Is there an efficient way to process it on the fly beside using tarfile library in python? Regards, name  Hi name, We always recommend to run jobs on your SCRATCH folder (/scratch/gilbreth/pham84), where has 200TB space. Right now, you only used 1.6TB/200TB, I am sure you should be okay to run the training there. It looks like you already have 1999k files there, I would recommend to archive files at Scratch. Let me know if you have questions or this did not make sense to you. $ myquota pham84 Type Location Size Limit Use Files Limit Use ============================================================================== home pham84 15.5GB 25.0GB 62% - - - scratch gilbreth 1.6TB 200.0TB 0.82% 1,999k 2,000k 100% depot bera89 1.4TB 3.0TB 48% - - - Cheers, name  Hi name, I'm not worrying about the storage quota on scratch. My problem is that the tar.gz file is too large (1.5TB) and I need to create the training data from this tar file. If I try to process it on the fly instead of extracting it to disk, it will be really slow. Is there an effective way to process this large file? Regards, name  Hi name, I see. Let me talk within my team about your question. I am not quite sure about the answer now. Will you keep you posted. Cheers, name  Hello name, Sorry for the delay. I would like to setup a meeting for us to discuss your needs and what sort of work-around we can provide. Lot's of folks on Gilbreth have a similar request. I think it really depends on what you're trying to do, but assuming you decompress (.tar instead of .tar.gz), I can guarantee that we can get higher performance operating on the one file than having 20M small files in directories. The issue is not just that we cannot support everyone having 20M inodes on the file system, but also the latency bottleneck in making per-file network requests on 20M small files in the training set. Cheers, name Lead Research Data Scientist Rosen Center for Advanced Computing Need additional help? Meet us on Mon-Thu 2-3 pm for informal coffee: http://www.rcac.purdue.edu/coffee  Hi name, Please let us know if you want to have a meeting to talk about this. This ticket system would be inactive on Friday (7/21/2023). After Friday, we won't be able to receive your message. You can let us know if you want a meeting or you are okay to close this ticket or if you want to keep our discussion via email, we can move this ticket to our new ticket system. Cheers, name  Hi, Yes, I would like to have a meeting with you guys to discuss this issue. I'm available today until 4pm or after 2pm on Thursday and Friday this week. If none of these works for you, please suggest a time slot. Thank you so much. Regards, name  Hi name, Are you on campus today? You are welcome to come by the Convergence Center after 2pm if you would like to have that meeting, or I can send you an invite for a Teams call. GL  Hi, something came up and I'm not sure that I can join the meeting this afternoon. Can I come tomorrow around 2pm instead? Regards, name  That's fine.When you say "come" do you want come by in-person? Or should I send you a Teams call invite for 2pm? GL  Oh yes, I meant the Team call. Sorry for the confusion. Regards, name  Hi name, Sent the invite, see you on the call tomorrow. GL  Hi RCAC, I've tried to work directly with the tar.gz file as one of you suggested. I even used multiprocessing with it, but apparently the size of the tar file is too big and will take forever to process the data. So I don't think it is a viable solution for me. Is it possible to increase the file limit for me for a month and then set it back to 2M files as default? I have a deadline coming up in less than 3 weeks and I really need to train my model now as it will take weeks to train. Thank you very much in advance. Regards, name_ From: name An Sent: Thursday, July 20, 2023 3:15 PM To: Central Incident Subject: Re: Customer Notice about Request to increase the number of files limit on Gilbreth's scratch ISSUE=1931083 PROJ=17 Oh yes, I meant the Team call. Sorry for the confusion. Regards, name  Hello name, Sorry for the delay, as I said when we spoke last I have been away at a conference and am getting back to things this week. To answer your immediate follow-up question; we've given people temporary bumps to their quota by 2-4M files but never 20M+ and I do not think we will satisfy this request. I want to clarify from your most recent follow-up, using a .tar.gz archive would indeed be slow because that is gzip compressed at the archive level, so to traverse the archive and pull out individual files, one must decompress the entire thing as it goes along to find the positions to seek to (that is just the nature of how .TAR is structured). You need to name-compress the archive and have it be a raw .tar file (note the missing .gz from the compression). You must also keep in mind that the initial start-up time may be a few minutes while it reads the file (much faster than gzip however because we aren't decompressing anything).Over the past few days I've gotten an alternative approach working using the entire ImageNet dataset (13M+ files) where you would not need to make any code changes. You can pack the data files into a single .squashfs image file (not unlike an archive format - see mksquashfs command). Instead of making changes to your code, you would containerize it using singularity/apptainer (think Docker) and mount the .squashfs image into the container as a local directory. Your code would see it as a normal directory as you are trying to achieve now. In either case, I'm happy to discuss these approaches more with you. We need to migrate this issue to the new ticketing system because Footprints is being decommissioned. Please send another message to and it should open a ticket in the new system where we can continue our conversation. Cheers, name Lead Research Data Scientist Rosen Center for Advanced Computing

I've shared this ticket with our scientists who have expertise in Gaussian. They would be in touch with you soon. Thanks, name  Hi Shri, Thank you for reaching out! I am currently traveling on vacation until July 4th, so I'll just chime in with my initial thoughts and then will leave you in my colleagues' capable hands. First of all, please do not use name's user guide on Gilbreth. While our clusters have a lot in common, they are significantly different from each other, so I'd suggest always using the right user guide as reference (https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/knowledge/gilbreth/run/examples/apps/gaussian) That said, it does look like our deployed 'subg16' script for the 'gaussian16/B.01-gpu' module on Gilbreth has a bug, and it passes an incorrect resource selection argument to the underlying sbatch command. From a quick glance, I have a feeling this may require somewhat of an investigation and re-work (@RCAC-ers - I am not sure how, but suspect an incorrect version of the wrapper crept into this installation). This might take us some time to untangle. In the interim... one option would be to use the 'rung16' wrapper instead (this is what 'subg16' uses internally anyways, so it's just the matter of calling it properly). The simplest invocation could leverage sbatch's built-in '--wrap' functionality: module load gaussian16/B01-gpu sbatch -N1 -n11 --gres=gpu:1 -A dflaher-h --time 24:00:00 --wrap="rung16 AC1test" (basically, you specify the necessary job parameters, and then '--wrap' flag at the end tells sbatch to generate a tiny submission script encompassing the command you want to execute). Note the quotes around the argument to the '--wrap' flag, they are important. This should work thanks to Slurm magic. Alternatively, you could use a full-blown batch job submission that calls Gaussian directly (see the very last example on the above user guide page). Thanks, name P.S. As a side note, note the '-n11' in my example above. This is important - your 'dflaher-h' queue on Gilbreth is anchored on H-subcluster nodes, and you only purchased 1 GPU (i.e. 1/3 of a full node, i.e. 11 CPU cores out of 32 total per node). So any request for more resources than this would either throw an error or leave the job waiting in the queue indefinitely. You _can_ get access to more resources than that, but only if you specify standby queue instead ('-A standby')... but remember that standby jobs are limited to at most 4 hours of walltime. -- name Rosen Center for Advanced Computing (RCAC)  Hi Shri, Do you have further questions? If not, I would tentative to mark this ticket as resolved. Thanks again for contact us! Please feel free to reach out if you have any question in the future! Good luck with your research! --- name, PhD Sr. Computational Scientist RCAC Research Computing Purdue University  Some people who received this message don't often get email from <mailto:. customernote: Hello,Thank you for contacting the Purdue IT Service Desk. I have forwarded your ticket to our Support team who will be able to further assist you. If you have any other issues or questions, please reply to this email or call us at . It seems you should have access to the department queue "biochem" on Bell currently. Did you encounter any issues accessing Bell? I do not see you have access to Gilbreth at the moment. Would you please let us know if you intended to have a group queue on Gilbreth? Which cluster(s) did name (tsheeley) want to get access to? For browsing our website pages, could you please clear the cache of your browser, restart your browser or computer and try it again? If the issue persists, please let us know. Thanks, name, Can we set up a time to discuss this over the phone? ~4:45 today or before 9 AM on Thurs.? As I am not an expert in this area, I cannot make sense of the information on rcacs website. We need access to Bell for running bioinformatics analyses on NGS datasets. I do not know which community cluster we should be going through, how to get there, etc. Thanks, name L. Kirchmaier, Ph.D. Associate Professor Department of Biochemistry & Purdue Center for Cancer Research Purdue University 175 S. University St. West Lafayette, IN 47907  Hi name forwarded your ticket to me. Since I am responsible for the bioinformatics applications on clusters, I may know better about your computing needs. If this works for you, I can send you the meeting invitation. title: Issues logging in the gateway
customernote: Dear Sir or Madam, Yesterday I tried to log in the cluster but when I tried to launch gateway, it says this [cid:id] I thought it was a temporary problem. But I am having the same issue today. And when I try to schedule coffee hour, when I tried to log in, it also directs me to a page with the above message. Could you please let me know why this is happening? And is there anything I need to do? Best, name Hi name, Thank you for reaching out! The issue could possibly related to the recent transition from BoilerKey to Purdue Login (https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/news/5920). Would you please try clearing the cache of your browser, restarting your browser or rebooting your computer and see if that helps? Thanks, name  Very helpful! Before I sent the email, I have restarted my laptop and it was still not working. But I just clear the cache of the browser and now it is working! Thanks name! Best, name  Hi name, Glad it works for you now. Thanks for letting me know! I'll mark this ticket as resolved then. Please feel free to contact us again if you have any questions or need any help. Thanks, name

title: Re: Account Ready
customernote: Some people who received this message don't often get email from . Learn why this is important<https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification> Thank you for helping me to create an account in RCAC. I am facing an issue while launching the Negishi cluster (screenshot attached) Could you pls check through it? Best, name [cid:id-895f-4455-a4bd-0836c4750e08]_ From: Rosen Center for Advanced Computing Sent: Wednesday, June 28, 2023 5:00 AM To: name Subject: Account Ready You don't often get email from . Learn why this is important<https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification> [RCAC]<https://www.rcac.purdue.edu> Hello name, Your account on name, Bell, Negishi has been created and are ready for use. Details about using these and other RCAC resources are included below._ You can access the clusters through the front-ends with your institution credentials using SSH<https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/knowledge> or Thinlinc<https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/knowledge>. You've been granted access to the following: name User guide https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/knowledge/name Front-end name.rcac.purdue.edu Home directory shared, 25GB Scratch space 200.00 TB space; 200,000 files Queues lslipche - 96 cores, 14 days standby - 4 hours Bell User guide https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/knowledge/bell Front-end bell.rcac.purdue.edu Home directory specific to Bell, 25GB Queues lslipche - 128 cores, 14 days standby - 4 hours Negishi User guide https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/knowledge/negishi Front-end negishi.rcac.purdue.edu Home directory specific to Negishi, 25GB Queues lslipche - 128 cores, 14 days standby - 4 hours Standby Queue You also have access to the "standby" queue. This queue utilizes idle cores from other queues. You can use this queue to run jobs of up to 4 hours. Wait times in standby will vary wildly (minutes to days) depending on cluster utilization and how many nodes your jobs request. Scratch Space Scratch space is available for storing large input and output data during computations. This space offers both a much larger quota and better performance than your home directory. There is no backup service for scratch directories and files not accessed or modified in the last 60 days will be removed<https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/policies/scratchpurge>. Files in scratch directories are not recoverable if they are purged or accidentally deleted. Archival Space Long-term archival space is also offered via the Fortress HPSS Archival system. Fortress stores files on a tape library and uses a tape robot to retrieve and store these files upon request. title: Cluster parallel computing with Matlab using parfor
customernote: Hello, I am trying to speed up my existing (serial) Matlab code by performing some of the tasks in parallel form, across multiple processors. However, I am not sure how to do this correctly. My code calculates the power spectrum of certain quantities on a surface (with 171045 nodes), over a time series of about 700,000 time steps. The data has to be read into memory from existing data files (saved at each time step), before the spectra can be calculated. To reduce the memory requirements of the job, I have modified the serial code to split up the domain into smaller groups of nodes, and perform the necessary operations for each group (one at a time). Because the most time-consuming name is the reading of the raw data from the different time steps into memory, I have opted to use a parfor-loop to parallelize this step. So, the pseudo-code is as follows: 1. Start Matlab script 2. Split up domain into groups of nodes 3. for each group: 3.1. parfor each time step: 3.1.1. open data file corresponding to the time step 3.1.2. store data from selected nodes into main data array 3.2. Calculate spectra using the main data array 3.3. Write spectra data into output file (for each group; I have a separate script to combine all the data from the different groups) 4. End Matlab script I have split the domain such that each group requires no more than 200 Gb worth of data to be read into memory. 3 compute nodes on name should provide sufficient memory for the job. I plan to submit a slurm job to run my Matlab script (described above), but without using an additional Matlab job submission script (which uses the Matlab "batch" function as described in https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/knowledge/scholar/run/examples/apps/matlab/parfor), for simplicity. How should I define the cluster profile to setup the Matlab workers, such that the memory and cores across the 3 compute nodes will be utilized in the parfor loop? I have tried running the script without defining a cluster profile. That defaulted to the "local" profile of 12 Matlab workers on name. However, the job crashed while reading the data into memory (step 3.1. in the pseudo-code), without throwing any error in the slurm job output. I guess it failed because of insufficient memory, perhaps because it only had access to the memory on one compute node. Thank you Regards, name Hi name, Thank you for contacting us. I will need sometime to explore with it as current session in User Guide is kind of out-dated and may not work (but feel free to try it and implement it into your workflow). As a reference for the cluster profile manager, here is my settings fyi (note: you can download from https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/knowledge/name/run/examples/apps/matlab/profile_manager, import it and modify). In 'Resource arguments for job submission.', I have '--nodes=2 --ntasks-per-node=24 --account=xxx --time=01:00:00'. Then I can validate and set this profile as 'default'. After the above set up, I can request for a parpool as much as 48 with 'parpool(48)'. I did not test how it works for the memory but the new job submitted by matlab parpool will get a total of two entire nodes and their total memory. Please go ahead and test if it works for you. Best regards, name Senior Computational Scientist Purdue Information Technology  Hi name, I tried setting up the cluster profile with the settings you mentioned, but it failed the validation tests (see attached pdf). The issue was probably with the arguments: "--account=xxx --time=01:00:00". Because after I removed those entries (i.e. resource arguments for job submission set as: "--nodes=2 --ntasks-per-node=24"), the validation tests were completed successfully. With this working cluster profile, I got an interactive slurm job with 3 compute nodes on name, and ran my Matlab program with the modules gcc/6.3.0 and matlab/R2022a. However, when I ssh-ed separately into the compute nodes and looked at the cpu/memory utilization, it appeared that only the main compute node (batch host) was being utilized. The other two compute nodes were practically idle. The program eventually failed with the following error, Error using parallel.internal.cluster.ClusterParforEngine/getCompleteIntervals Task 25 failed execution while executing parfor loop Alternatively, with the "local" cluster profile, the same job (on 3 compute nodes on name) worked (it didn't fail). However, similar to the previous case, only the main compute node (batch host) was being utilized. The other two compute nodes were idle. Thanks Regards, name  Hi name, Sorry I should have been much clearer about the profile. It should be the account/queue name after '-- account=' (I.e. you should replace xxx with the actual account/queue you want to use). For example, if I want to request resources for 1 hour from 'standby', I need to put '--account=standby --nodes=2 --ntasks- per-node=24 --time=01:00:00'. You can change the parameters as needed. If you run with this profile (don't forget to set it as default), it (matlab) will actually submit a job named with 'jobx' (e.g. job3) with the specific resources request. Inside of this matlab workflow, I believe you can take advantage of the cross-node computation. While you were using the interactive session to run matlab, it will only landed on the 'main compute node' as you mentioned and cannot use resources from other nodes. Can you give it another try and see if you can make it? Best, name  Hi name, Thanks for the clarification. After setting the "account" option correctly, the job ran without crashing. However, it went out of control and kept submitting multiple jobs on the queue. To be clear, I first submitted a slurm job (--nodes=3, --ntasks-per-node=24; job id:id) to run my matlab script. It was fine until it started a parallel pool using the cluster profile, where it created another slurm job (3 nodes; job id:id; name: job3). Another weird thing is that the slurm output from the matlab script stated that a parallel pool of 12 workers was created, even though the cluster profile set NumWorkers as 24. And when the matlab script reached the start of the parfor loop, it created numerous 3 node slurm jobs (job id:id to 20237010_121; name: job4). I tried cancelling the main slurm job id:id. This terminated the main slurm job (id:id), and the job that was created at the parpool step (id:id). However, the other jobs associated with the parfor step (id:id to 20237010_121) kept appearing even after I cancelled them. For example, jobs 20237010_21 to 20237010_25 were created and running at the same time. I submitted an scancel command to terminate these jobs. After these jobs were terminated, 20237010_26 to 20237010_31 appeared on the queue. This went on for quite a while until it I entered "scancel 20237010_*" to terminate all the jobs at once. If you want, you can see the relevant files at this working directory: /scratch/name/jngoh/sweptfinsbli/arora2019b_meshv2b_runv3d/wall_plate/spectra/calc The Matlab script is "matlab_surface_wall_plate_04_spectra_calc_parallel_2a.m". The parpool command is found on line 38; the parfor command is at line 276. The cluster profile used is "matlabclusterprofile_brown3.mlsettings". The slurm job submission script is "run_matlab_surface_wall_plate_04_spectra_calc_2a.m". The slurm output for the main job is "slurm-20237008.out". I am not sure what I am doing wrong here. How many jobs should I expect Matlab to submit with the "parpool" and "parfor" commands? Thanks Regards, name  Hi name, Thank you for the updates. Yes matlab would submit several jobs during its parfor run. Those jobs with id 20237010_xx should be regarded as job array (sub-jobs submitted by a main job). So you may not be able to cancel one of them and stop the entire job array. I am not 100% sure about the mechanisms inside of matlab parallel job submitting so may need more time to explore. As we have moved from FootPrints to Team Dynamix as the new ticket system, I will close this ticket. But let's keep this conversation offline and I will get back to you when I have updates. Please also feel free to let me know any findings from your side. My email is Best, name

title: Request to get access to ANSYS
customernote: Hello, My name is name and I am a PhD student at Purdue. I am reaching out to you to seek your help in getting access to ANSYS software remotely. I tried to install ANSYS student version locally on my Mac. But I think it is only compatible with Windows. Request if you could suggest some options to get access to ANSYS. Thank you. With Best Regards, ------------------------------- name PhD Student Purdue University email id:id are Purdue. What we make moves the world forward. Hi name, Thank you for contacting us! For remote access, We have Linux version ANSYS installed on RCAC clusters, but all the RCAC resources need to be purchased before you can access them. If your PI or your department has access to any of our clusters, you can request access through this link: https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/account/request. Since Ansys license is maintained by ECN. You will also need to contact ECN to be added to Ansys unix group, so that you can use it on RCAC resources: https://engineering.purdue.edu/ECN/AboutUs/ContactUs Or from google results, you may try creating a Windows virtual machine on your Mac using software like Parallels Desktop or VMWare Fusion. You can then install and run ANSYS within the virtual machine. Best, name

title: Bell Cluster PNW
customernote: Good afternoon, My name is name Bartholomew and I'm apart of Information Services at PNW. We have several faculty and staff members that use the Bell Cluster for research. The main programs these members use are Star-CCM+ and Ansys. Both of these programs license from our license server hosted at PNW (license01). We have a new license server that will be replacing license01; so our team is working with Purdue Security to get the firewalls in place. I have 2 requests for this. 1. Can you let me know the address(es) of the Bell Cluster? 2. Would there be anything need done on your end to ensure that our new license server can communicate with the bell cluster? 3. Can we get accounts setup so members of our team can test functionality on the Bell Cluster? Thank you, and please let me know if you have any questions. name Bartholomew | Central Desktop Administration Engineer Information Services Purdue University Northwest <mailto: [image002] Hi name, Thank you for contacting us! For you three questions: 1. I have assigned this ticket to our system admins to ask for the IP address range for bell nodes. 2. We don't host starccm license or ansys. There is no firewall blocking outgoing connection from bell. You will only need to allow bell's IP range on your firewall. 3. You can ask the group manager of those groups who have account on bell to add you into their group as a member or group manager, so that you can do some test works on bell. Please let me know if you have any questions. Best,name
technotes: Entered on 2023-06-29 at 16:12:04 by Hong, Yang :Hi ops team, can you please help me check the IP address range of bell cluster?

title: Requesting Data Depot Account for TSUNOMI Project
customernote: Some people who received this message don't often get email from . Learn why this is important<https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification> ---- External Email: Use caution with attachments, links, or sharing data ---- Hello, My name is Zack Tarsaswarm. I work with Saab Inc, and am a member of the TSUNOMI project, working with Professor name (CC-ed) and other Purdue faculty. As part of TSUNOMI, we will be collecting sensor data at Purdue and are investigating how best to store and share that data between the Purdue and Saab teams. Dr. name recently forwarded me the data storage guide<https://guides.lib.purdue.edu/DataStorage> for Purdue. From looking at the various options it seems that the "Data Depot" might be what we're looking for, and I wanted to see if we could stand up one of those 100 GB trial accounts for the project to see if this would work for our purposes? Can you help us with getting this set up? Thanks! Zack Tarsaswarm Senior Staff Machine Learning Software Engineer Autonomous & Undersea Systems Saab, Inc. M + www.saabinc.com<http://www.saabinc.com/> [cid:id] This e-mail (including attachments) contains contents owned by Saab Group AB and/or its subsidiaries, affiliated companies or customers and covered by the laws of Sweden, the US, or Canada (federal, state or provincial). The information is intended to be confidential and may be legally privileged. If you are not the intended recipient, you are hereby notified that any retention, dissemination, distribution, interception or copying of this communication is strictly prohibited and may subject you to further legal action. Reply to the sender if you received this email by accident, and then delete the email and any attachments. Hi Zack, Thank you for contacting us! We only setup Data Depot account for Purdue faculty or staff members. If you would like to sharing data with Prof. name, it can be achieved in following ways: 1. Learn why this is important<https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification> Hello Rcac Team, I ran into a problem I have never faced until now. I suspect there is corruption for the conda environment that causing it unable to locate the GLIBCXX. Usually it can be resolved by creating a new environment. title: Question about transferring data
customernote: Some people who received this message don't often get email from . Learn why this is important<https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification> To whom it may concern, Hope this email finds you well before the weekend. I recently need to transfer a few TB data from the computer of my former postdoc, Dr name Remington (cced here). My group has purchased 24 TB for data depot recently. I am wondering if there is a way to allow name, a non-Purdue user, to send the data to our space in data depot. Eagerly looking forward to your feedback. name, PhD Associate Professor Department of Medicinal Chemistry and Molecular Pharmacology name E. Heine Pharmacy Building (RHPH) Building, Room 504B 575 W Stadium Avenue West Lafayette, IN 47907 o: LinkedIn<https://nam04.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fin%2Fhttps%3A%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fin%2Flijianing%2F&data=05%7C01%7Crcac-help%40purdue.edu%7C14f15f4ee8504a7c0ed208db79933c37%7C4130bd397c53419cb1e58758d6d63f21%7C0%7C0%7C638237445506611133%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=Naqyzq%2BCYLVH%2Fe1v2HaTeWWftgJZersjKtTO7sco0fA%3D&reserved=0> Group Website<https://web.ics.purdue.edu/~li4578/> [Shape Description automatically generated with low confidence] [Purdue University]<https://www.purdue.edu/?utm_source=signature&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=purdue> Hi name, Thank you for contacting us. First of all, depot space is only accessible to Purdue users (i.e. they must have a valid Purdue account) so this non-Purdue user cannot access to depot directly from outside. However, you can file the R4P (Request for Privilege) to grant a Purdue account for collaborators outside. Documentation on the process can be found here: https://www.purdue.edu/hr/buspur/supportingDocs/r4pRequestorInstructions.pdf Once the process is done and name got a Purdue account, you may add name's Purdue account to your group (the unix group 'li4578-data' which controls access to your depot folder './li4578/data'). Then you will be able to share data in that folder. Let me know if you have further questions. Best regards, name Senior Computational Scientist Purdue Information Technology  Thanks. I have filled it, and it says: Successfully created new request with id 125930 in org unit 00000357 and the approvers have been notified  Hi, Thank you for the updates. Feel free to let me know when the account is ready so we can move on to add it to your depot space. Best, name  Hi name and name, I was out of town on a two-weeks vacation, so chiming in late and mostly for completeness sake. The way name suggested is perfectly valid (do an R4P for the external collaborator, this generates a valid Purdue career account for them, then add this account to your group in our system to grant them access to your Depot space so they could upload necessary data). This is the usual route we recommend for long-term collaborations (and the only one possible if cluster access is needed along with just data). Looks like you are well underway on this path, so everything is getting close to successful finish. For completeness sake, I wanted to mention that there is also an alternative that does not involve R4P and/or full-scale access to your Depot space, and could be occasionally very handy for one-offs or short-term data transfers. It would involve Globus (very similar to what we did when transferring Vermont data). In this scenario, name could create a Globus share anchored in a specific subfolder of your Depot space, and grant name write access to this share (and only this share!) in Globus. This is very handy when you need a data drop to or from people who are not at Purdue and do not have accounts on our storage systems (this is the beauty of Globus sharing). title: PURR account in Fortress
customernote: Hello, This is Jerry name, software developer on Purdue University Research Repository(PURR). I would like to request an account in Fortress for PURR, from where we want to start our project to move the 10-year datasets from PURR to Fortress. name and name from our side have been worked with you in the past weeks, so please let me know if you need anything from me. Thank you, Jerry Jerry(name Software Developer at Purdue University Research Repository Purdue University Libraries and School of Information Studies <mailto: Hi Jerry, Thanks for reaching out! I have passed your message to my team members. You would hear from them soon. Happy holiday! --- name, PhD Sr. Computational Scientist RCAC Research Computing Purdue University  Thank you, name. Jerry  Hi name, I didnt hear from anyone in your team so far. Can you please ask if anyone give an update? Thank you, Jerry  Hi Jerry and name, Terribly sorry, this is my fault for being swamped and not responding earlier! Fortress accounts come as an add-on with any other RCAC resource. The easiest way to achieve this would be to set up a Data Depot space for the PURR team, and that would automatically provision a shared group space on Fortress. I know PURR used to have a Depot space, but eventually decided to delete it due to lack of need. Would you be ok with recreating it (on a small free 100GB scale), essentially as a door opener? Thanks, name Rosen Center for Advanced Computing (RCAC)  Hi name, Thank you for your email and completely understand about the timing. Recreating the space sounds great. Jerry and I spoke this morning and hell be working to get this all set with you all. What information do you all need for doing this? Also, Jerry and I wanted to be sure and ask about how to access the space once it is recreated. Thanks for your help with this! - name, PhD (she/they) Research Data Systems Manager Purdue University Research Repository (PURR)<https://purr.purdue.edu/> Purdue University Libraries <mailto: (  Hi name and Jerry, Apologies again for a delay. Turns out, while we did delete the old /depot/purr, the PURR group itself (as a unit in our system) was not removed. So the space on Fortress exists, and I just need to add you into this group. My bad, I should have remembered that that earlier... when PURR Depot was deleted, all we did was deleting _a resource_ that the PURR group owned, not the _group itself_. So last night I: * Added name in a manager role to PURR group in our system * Added Jerry in a group member role * Removed old managers (pmeunier and scaldron) This morning noticed a small back-end glitch in the addition process (which affected Jerry a lot and name a little). I think I fixed it just now and it should propagate overnight, I am keeping an eye. If you login to https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/account/myinfo you should see yourselves as being members of "PURR Hub Group". From there, under "Groups", name would also be able to manage the group (add/remove people, etc). Direct access to /group/purr on Fortress is controlled by membership in 'purr-data' Unix group - so make sure to tick that box for anyone that needs it (but see the Globus discussion below, perhaps this may not be necessary) ----------------------------------------- Now, how to put things into Fortress? The three supported methods are SFTP, HSI and HTAR, and Globus (https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/knowledge/fortress/storage). SFTP can be command-line or GUI based. HSI and HTAR are command-line tools (HSI looks similar to old-school FTP, HTAR mimics regular tar). HSI and HTAR are installed on all RCAC systems, and we have them packages for download if people want to install on their computers (Linux only). And of course Globus is Globus. All in all, I think we should setup a Globus-based archival workflow. Universal, both GUI and scriptable, reliable, and so on. Now, there are two ways of doing this: 1. Jerry (and any other PURR staff that will be doing transfers) can go to the Fortress primary endpoint (the main "Purdue Fortress HPSS Archive" collection), navigate to /group/purr and start transferring. This is a direct route, all files are written to Fortress with the writer's individual credentials (but this is fine as long as they are members of the 'purr-data' Unix group) 2. Someone (probably name) logs in to the primary Fortress endpoint and makes a *Globus share* (a.k.a. Guest Collection) anchored at /group/purr. Then you make a few people co-managers of that share in case you get hit by a bus, and then you have a flexibility of doling out read or write permissions on the share (or specific subfolders inside the share) to whoever needs to have access to it. This is conceptually very similar to what we did on the PURR side for uploads. The advantages of the second approach are multiple: - Familiar, and done in many other place. Essentially, this is how Globus recommends doing it. - Flexible access controls on the share * People don't need to be added to the 'purr-data' Unix group, all permissions are regulated in Globus * 'purr-data' is essentially all or nothing. Globus permissions can be as granular or general as you need them. - No matter who does the transfer, all files are written with credentials of the person who created the share. This helps against occasional obscure "permissions denied" errors on the filesystem level. Not critical (and if such errors creep in, we can always easily fix them), but one less support ticket. What do you think?  Hi name, Thank you for creating the Globus group for us. I tried accessing both the Fortress primary endpoint and the PURR directory, but Im not able to. Please see attached. Jerry  Moving to new ticket system, Team Dynamix (TDX)

title: Working with Large Files on Gilbreth for an Extended Period of Time
customernote: Hello, I'm currently a graduate student in Dr. name' lab in structural name. We're interested in computing on the clusters, and I already have access to Gilbreth through the pi4d-h group. Our lab focuses on cryo-electron tomography and all the computing that comes with it, and the files we work with are very large. In general, one fully reconstructed bin1 tomogram is 100+ gb and a full tomography project can be terabytes of data. If I'm looking at my quota correctly, it says I have 25gb in my home directory and 200tb in my scratch directory. The 200tb will work for us, since we plan on working on our tomograms in batches and probably never a full project at once. How often does scratch get emptied? A project can take months to complete, so we're worried about the scratch getting cleared out before we can finish what we're working on. Is there a way we can stop the scratch directory from clearing out or another more long-term solution or place to store our data on Gilbreth? Thank you for your help, please let me know if you have any questions! Best, name Hi name, Thank you for contacting us. Files are purged from scratch directories not accessed or had content modified in 60 days. The owner of these files will receive a notice one week before removal via email. You may consider purchasing into data depot space (it's $70/per TB/per year) so you can have long-term data access for the entire group. Another good option is Fortress which is designed for long-term data storage. You will have access to unlimited Fortress space for free once you have cluster access. And we provide 'hsi' and 'htar' commands which are both easy-to-use interfaces into the archive and can be used to copy files into the archive interactively or even automatically at the end of your regular job submission scripts. Here is an introduction of Fortress fyi: https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/knowledge/fortress?all=true. The disadvantage of Fortress is that it's much slower to extract data out of it as it will reply on actual physical arms to read out data from tapes. Let me know if you have further questions. Best regards, name Senior Computational Scientist Purdue Information Technology  Hi, Since we haven't heard feedback from you for some time, issues seem to have been solved. I will temporarily mark this ticket as resolved. Feel free to re-open it or send us a new one if you have similar issues. Best, name

customernote: Hello, I am trying to run a job with matlab parallel on Bell. Ideally I need about 20 cores to run the task. Currently, I have two interactive sessions in the queue. I have two questions about this. A Bell-related question: One of the sessions requested has 12 cores and 2 hours of time, but I have been waiting the entire day for that. In the past, the waiting time was much lower, so I am not sure if I am making a mistake, or if there is a more efficient way to ask for these resources. A Matlab-related question: I noticed that sometimes one core goes out of memory. Do you know how I can find out (and later set on Bell) the memory needed for each core? Thank you, name Hi name, Thank you for contacting us. For your questions: 1) It's simply because that there are not enough CPU resources available from your queue 'krannert'. If you can navigate to 'Cluster -> Bell Shell Access' and type 'slist' in the pop-out terminal, you will see the current usage for the queues. e.g. As I am seeing right now: ############### Current Number of Cores Node Account Total Queue Run Free Max Walltime Type ============== ================================= ============== ====== debug 256 249 0 256 00:30:00 A gpu 512 0 128 384 G highmem 1024 1083 865 159 1-00:00:00 B krannert 512 233 512 0 14-00:00:00 A multigpu 48 0 0 48 G standby 48896 8657 1762 14805 04:00:00 A ############### 2) By default you will get ~2GB/per core for your session job. e.g. If you get 12 cores, you will get ~24 GB memory. This can also be found in the terminal mentioned above by typing 'jobinfo jobid', where jobid is the number you got after the MATLAB in the title of 'my interactive sessions' page. I don't think you can modify this memory per core from Bell gateway. You can try 'highmem' queue which is configured as ~8GB/per core if you need more memory per core. Let me know if you have further questions. Best regards, name Senior Computational Scientist Purdue Information Technology  Hello, After running in parallel on Matlab for a few hours (I was running a job with 64 nodes, and used just 20 in parallel, to avoid crash), I got an error message, and apparently I can no longer run in parallel. Do you know if the system is down, or its my fault? Matlab message says I exceeded disk quota. Thanks. Happy 4th. FR  OK I just noticed that the system is down. From: name Sent: Tuesday, July 4, 2023 4:23 AM To: Central Incident Subject: RE: Customer Notice about help with matlab parallel job on Bell ISSUE=1936345 PROJ=17 Hello, After running in parallel on Matlab for a few hours (I was running a job with 64 nodes, and used just 20 in parallel, to avoid crash), I got an error message, and apparently I can no longer run in parallel. Do you know if the system is down, or its my fault? Matlab message says I exceeded disk quota. Thanks. Happy 4th. FR  Hi, There might be some glitches for Bell scratch yesterday morning but now it should be gone. If your workflow was related to Bell scratch space and you saw an error message 'no space left on device', it should be related. But it should not be your case (when you saw the error 'disk quota exceeded'). This issue is related to the fact that your $HOME folder is full. The solution would be clean up some spaces in your home directory by either deleting or moving out files from the home directory. You can fulfill this task through actions via gateway.bell -> Files -> Home Directory or through ssh to bell. Again, you can still use the above terminal on Bell and type 'myquota' to check your current quota (it shows 100% full for you $HOME now). Best, name  Hi, Since we haven't heard feedback from you for some time, issues seem to have been solved. I will temporarily mark this ticket as resolved. Feel free to re-open it or send us a new one if you have similar issues. Best, name  Hi name, Sorry for not getting back to you. Thank you for your help. I still had a few issues, even after using Highmem, but it largely solved the problem. Thank you, FR  Hi name, Glad to help. Please send us new tickets if you need further assistance for those issues. Thank you. Best, name

title: Inquiry Regarding Purdue BOX.COM and Data Storage Options
customernote: Hello, I have some questions regarding the use of Purdue BOX.COM and its storage capabilities. Currently, I have been utilizing my personal Purdue BOX.COM cloud storage to collect sensor and machine data from collaborative projects with local Indiana manufacturing companies. The data mainly consists of sound/noise files in WAV format and CSV files from IoT sensors like power meters and accelerometers. Consequently, the daily data size is quite substantial. Recently, I encountered an issue where data collection was halted due to the limited storage capacity of my BOX.COM account. I had believed that the storage was unlimited, but upon reviewing the Purdue BOX.COM policy, I discovered it is actually limited to 1 TB. Consequently, I now need to migrate all previous data and, more importantly, find an alternative method for data collection. Therefore, I am considering purchasing the BOX.COM Research Lab Folder from Purdue (https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/storage/boxfolder). I have a couple of questions regarding this option. [https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/files/resources/boxfolder/resource.jpg]<https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/storage/boxfolder> Box Research Lab Folder<https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/storage/boxfolder> A Box Research Lab Folder is a managed storage solution built on top of the Box.com cloud platform, for research labs to share and collabora... www.rcac.purdue.edu 1. In the description of the Box Research Lab Folder, it is mentioned that the data storage is unlimited. Can you please confirm if this information is correct? 1. Am I able to purchase the Box Research Lab Folder myself, or do I need to seek authorization from my PI to make the purchase on my behalf? Thank you for your assistance in addressing these queries. Best, Eunseob Eunseob name Ph.D. student School of Mechanical Engineering, Purdue University 205 Gates Rd. Rm. 1101 West Lafayette, IN 47906 Lab webpage: name Laboratory<https://web.ics.purdue.edu/~jun25/> If your email is bounced, please email me to <mailto:. Hi Eunseob, Thanks for contacting us! I'd like to give you some updates to your questions before I get off from work today. For Box Research Lab Folder, all data kept in the Box Research Lab Folder remains owned by the research group's lead faculty. So it should be applied by a faculty member. For your first question about if there is a quota limit for this folder. I'll need to double check within my team to give you more comprehensive answer. Will update you later. Cheers, --- name, PhD Sr. Computational Scientist RCAC Research Computing Purdue University  Hello name, Thank you for your reply. Yes. Please let me know after you confirm the quota limit. I haven't calculated the size of data per day yet. I will estimate the amount of data required daily basis for data collection. I will ask the PI of the project to purchase the Box Research Lab Folder. Best, Eunseob  Hello, Looping in Rob Blue the BOX admin as well. Your personal space should have been configured with a 5TB quota, and that can be raised if needed. You can also proceed with a BOX Research Folder (L1 on the Security scale ) and then that folder would have BOX ownership attributed to the L1 system account and would not impact your personal storage quota. Let us know how you would like to proceed. title: Files to be copied in a Permanent location
customernote: Some people who received this message don't often get email from . Learn why this is important<https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification> Hello, Hope you are well. My username is mitra57. I received an email that my files from scratch will be purged on 11th July 2023. I don't want my files to be purged; rather, it would be helpful if they were copied to a more permanent location. Please provide me with your necessary feedback. Thank you! Best, name Hi name, Thanks for contacting us. Yes, scratch folder would be purged regularly, this is the policy because scratch is not designed for permanent storage. We have Data Depot and Fortress available for long-term storage. Your lab has 100GB space on Data Depot. You can check our user guide about how to transfer your files to /depot/mukher28. If you need more space, you need to talk to your supervisor, name, about Data Depot purchase. Data stored on Data Depot won't be purged. Fortress is tape-based storage you can put your files there, but not good for quick I/O process. Depot and Fortress won't be purged. Thus, if you are seeking permanent storage, Data Depot and Fortress would be the solution on RCAC clusters. Scratch purge will happen regularly. Cheers, --- name, PhD Sr. Computational Scientist RCAC Research Computing Purdue University

Best, name [cid:id-34bd-45e9-9806-2bf024ce9d19] Hi name, Thank you for calling Purdue IT Service Desk. Purdue has removed the Boilerkey login requirement, so you will no longer need your pin,push anymore. Instead read the following instructions to login into the new Purdue portal. When logging in, use your career account username for the login (), and for the password field you'll need to use your career account password. Then you will need to approve the notification on the Duo-mobile app on your phone.See detailed instructions below, if this doesn't work, please call into the Customer Service Center at (. PUSH - push with Duo-Mobile app confirmationUsername: yourusernamePassword: careeraccountpassword This will 'push' a authorization request notification to your phone.NOTE: Once you press the login button, you will only have 15 seconds to open the mobile notification, and click 'approve'. If you can't complete this in 15 seconds, or you're in an area with a slow mobile connection, you may want to try "Other options" Other OptionsNOTE: If you're in an area with a slow mobile connection, or you need more time to complete your login, use this option.Open the Duo Mobile app on your phone, select the drop down arrow under "Purdue University", tap the refresh icon and it will generate a new 6 digit pass code. Once you've clicked "other options" choose the "Duo Mobile Passcode" and input the 6 digit number. Password Reset If you are still having issues then you may need to reset your career account password.You can reset your career account password by going to boilerbot.purdue.edu and selecting "Password Reset" where you will be given further instructions by the AI chat box. If you have any issues with boilerbot then you will need to call us at and reference the ticket number in the subject line. Through some online scrolling I found this post on stack exchange (https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/265668/g-doesnt-recognize-standard-14-std-c14<https://nam04.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Funix.stackexchange.com%2Fquestions%2F265668%2Fg-doesnt-recognize-standard-14-std-c14&data=05%7C01%7Crcac-help%40purdue.edu%7C77a0a2222eab4fd47c7008db7d7b068d%7C4130bd397c53419cb1e58758d6d63f21%7C0%7C0%7C638241739826232619%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=2DFK77gSvV6a95RYj3I0ZUOGLXM4PGzU7QdcIJZaNW0%3D&reserved=0>) which proposes a potential solution. However, I cannot find where this command is even called to try and implement the fix. I have attached a src folder which should be nearly identical as the one I am trying to use on the cluster. It is not the exact one, though. I have been struggling to implement this software package for about 2 weeks now, so any help would be greatly appreciated. Let me know if you have any questions. Thank you! Have a good day, name Howe MSME Student Complex Flow Lab ( Hi name, Thanks for contacting us! First of all, I would mention that you were sending three tickets to us, with three different ticket number, 1937286, 1937311, and 1937323 (this one). I think they are the same. I guess this is a systematically mistake, sometimes we receive multiple tickets. To keep our communication in one place, I would close the other two and leave current one (1937323) open. It seems the error is related to GCC compiler. Can you share more about your workflow, like what modules you loaded, what libraries you installed before you configure rheoTool? Cheers, --- name, PhD Sr. Computational Scientist RCAC Research Computing Purdue University  I loaded gcc, openmpi, openfoam, hypre, openblas, and netlib-lapack. I commented out the sudo commands in installPetsc and finished the configuration manually according to the attached configure command. Let me know if you have any other questions, thanks! Thanks, name (He/Him) PhD Candidate Department of Statistics Purdue University https://loriaj.github.io/<https://nam04.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Floriaj.github.io%2F&data=05%7C01%7Crcac-help%40purdue.edu%7Cd51ad90bb00249d4fbdd08db7d93e8d1%7C4130bd397c53419cb1e58758d6d63f21%7C0%7C0%7C638241846433976477%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=4Gr%2FdTp8uNcIEQj4GFSPvFf7mpjS2f%2BCywNjE0ozwm4%3D&reserved=0> Hi name, Currently, r/4.1.2 and r/4.2.2 are built with gcc/6.3.0. You may need to install older version of glment and cran. Use commands like: devtools::install_version("glmnet", version = "4.0", repos = "http://cran.us.r-project.org") I didn't find what is the latest version that can work with gcc/6.3.0. You can do some research and see if older version can fit your needs. Also, we have r/4.1.1 container version installed on name. You can load it by module load biocontainers/default, then module load r/4.1.1. I did a quick test, it looks like glment 4.1.7 can be installed in this R version: > packageVersion("glmnet") [1] \u20184.1.7\u2019 You can also try this r/4.1.1 container. Best, name  Hi, Thanks! I managed to install glmnet, using your suggestion! What do I do? Thanks name Professor, Department of Entomology Purdue University name 901 W State Street West Lafayette, IN, 47907 USA (he, him, his) Hi Prof. name, Thank you for contacting us! Login for the RCAC website, Open OnDemand gateway sites, and Globus (which are all based on CAS) has changed. Login for SSH and Thinlinc has not. title: Help
customernote: Hi, I have a few problems with gilbeth/name. 1. I am on Dr. name's group but I cannot access her Depot directory even though on her end it says I am given permissions 2. I am using an ubuntu/linux and the terminal keeps freezing and logging me out of sessions while I am working after 5 mins of being on there. Originally, I was using a windows system and an ssh client and this was happening, but I rebooted my pc into linux to prevent this exact thing from happening. But now that it is still happening I am very frustrated because I never would be using Linux if this was going to still be an issue. It seems to be a bug on my account and not others. Please help me :') I am sad. Thanks, name Hi name, It sounds like a network issues: your network might be unstable, causing your SSH sessions to drop. A good solution (also what I am using now) is to download a Thinlinc client: https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/knowledge/gilbreth/accounts/login/thinlinc ThinLinc is that it allows you to start a remote desktop session and then disconnect from it without ending the session. When you close your ThinLinc client window, the session continues to run on the server. This allows you to reopen the ThinLinc client and reconnect to the same session later, with all your applications still open and running exactly as you left them. Best, name  Hi name, I used an ethernet last night (: I do not think it is an internet issues. Also do you have a potential resolution for the Depot Directory issue? Sorry for the inconvenience and thank you so much. name  Hi name, Please try the Thinlinc client and see if it helps. As for your depot permission, you should have access to depot/lslipche, depot/lslipche/apps and depot/lslipche/data, based on your account setup. When you tried to go to the depot folder, what error message did you get? Can you please send us a screenshot? Best, name  HI! Thank you very much. The Depot folder is now working. I still am having issues with my account. I have tried signing to name/gilbreth in on a pc with ethernet on campus as well that is ubuntu terminal and I am still having issues. I was wondering if if there is anyway you can take a look at my account please??? I talked with a few others, and no one else has this issue where they get booted off the account every 5 mins. Thanks, name  Hi name, Which client or terminal you used to login to cluster now? There is no setup that will let user lost connection every 5 mins on the cluster side. We have Coffee Hour Consultation services Monday through Thursday each week, today is online section. You can make a reservation and have a share-screen meeting with us to check your terminal setup: https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/coffee Best, name

Here's what I get: [cid:id] I believe I have already signed the NDA but let me know if I need to update it. Is there anything else I need to do to get added to the list of authorized users? Thanks, name. Hi everyone, Usually it takes about 2-4 hours between adding someone to the group in our web tool, and the change propagating through the clusters (there are couple cron jobs involved internally, so depends on their alignment). But given that Mark did the addition yesterday, this already happened. I think what you are seeing now is a fine semantic difference between 'id' and 'id jones105' - a plain 'id' show your group affiliations *in this running shell* (as it was started, i.e. before the addition). Whereas an 'id jones105' would show group membership *of the user* (as the cluster knows them). Normally these two views are identical... but not during membership changes. And 'id jones105' does shows the cae2 group as expected. TL;DR: Just open a new terminal window and that shell process will get blessed with updated memberships. Or log out/in (i.e. terminate existing thinlinc session and start new one). Thanks, name Rosen Center for Advanced Computing (RCAC)  Hi all, There might be some weird issue for Footprint system so you might not receive name's previous respond. I will paste his answer here again: ######################## Hi everyone, Usually it takes about 2-4 hours between adding someone to the group in our web tool, and the change propagating through the clusters (there are couple cron jobs involved internally, so depends on their alignment). But given that Mark did the addition yesterday, this already happened. I think what you are seeing now is a fine semantic difference between 'id' and 'id jones105' - a plain 'id' show your group affiliations *in this running shell* (as it was started, i.e. before the addition). Whereas an 'id jones105' would show group membership *of the user* (as the cluster knows them). Normally these two views are identical... but not during membership changes. And 'id jones105' does shows the cae2 group as expected. TL;DR: Just open a new terminal window and that shell process will get blessed with updated memberships. Or log out/in (i.e. terminate existing thinlinc session and start new one). Thanks, name Rosen Center for Advanced Computing (RCAC)  Thanks for your help... I seem to have access now so I believe this is resolved. Cheers, name.  Great, thanks for the update! Marking the ticket as resolved. title: FW: Question about data security
customernote: Good afternoon, I had the below restricted data question sent to me by one of our Sociology faculty members. Can you provide any details and if this would be a good fit for Weber? Thanks, Jess Jess P Maynard Purdue Information Technology Director of Information Technology, College of Liberal Arts o: [signature_521137663] From: name A Date: Friday, July 7, 2023 at 12:51 PM To: Maynard, Jess P Subject: Question about data security Hi Jess, I'm writing to ask for your help with a question I have about data security. I just left you a voicemail as well. Below is the email I sent to IT earlier this week. I've been trying to get clarification on this issue for a few weeks now and really need to get this resolved so that I can submit the data request. I've been working with name (Information Systems Security Manager) but he directed me to work with CLA IT. If I'm granted access to the data, he will sign the data use agreement. ---- I am writing to ask for assistance with security requirements for restricted use data from the National Center for Health Statistics that I am applying to access and analyze for a recently submitted grant proposal. I am writing to find out if the storage at Purdue meets the requirements outlined below, or if I need to have an air-gapped computer installed in my office. For example, is there a secure server where I can store my data? Can I use my regular office computer to analyze the data based on the requirements below? This is my first time accessing this kind of data and I don't fully understand where I would need to store the data so that it fits the security requirements. Thank you in advance for your help! The requirements for data storage and access are: "DVS restricted data may not be accessed outside of the U.S.A. and should be stored on, and accessed from, the secure computer system of the affiliated organization or institution. If a secure computer system is not available, the data may be stored on a password-protected, encrypted computer protected by anti-malware and anti-virus software. Storage and access of data files using a cloud-based system is not permitted." Follow up information for the data storage requirements is online: "The data files should be stored on, and accessed from, the secure computer system of the researchers affiliated organization or institution. This means that files will be housed on a server that is behind a firewall, has data encryption, permits file access only to the approved researchers, and has encrypted network communications; the researcher would then access the files from a password-protected institutional desktop or laptop. If a secure computer system is not available, files should be stored on an encrypted, password-protected, stand-alone computer or laptop protected by anti-virus and anti-malware software. The computer or laptop should be air-gapped for additional security as feasible. Permission from NCHS is required to store data files on a personal computer or laptop." https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/nvss/nvss-restricted-data.htm<https://nam04.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cdc.gov%2Fnchs%2Fnvss%2Fnvss-restricted-data.htm&data=05%7C01%7Crcac-help%40purdue.edu%7Cab95dbc70502412330f908db7f160ee4%7C4130bd397c53419cb1e58758d6d63f21%7C0%7C0%7C638243504932804263%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=krXBk8SM98rEvUBOLPGo5ROk4udatsQaBu%2FfUJMfSh4%3D&reserved=0> There is also a follow up question that must be answered on the application: "Please describe your institutions data protection procedures, and if possible, state who will be responsible for the security of the DVS restricted data." If you have suggestions for the language to use in answering this, that would be very helpful. title: Ask for help: Disk quota exceeded error
customernote: [Some people who received this message don't often get email from . Learn why this is important at https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification ] Hi there, I hope the email find you well. My name is name, a Purdue Phd student at CS department. I am writing to ask for advice on using the Bell cluster. Yesterday I started a Jupyter notebook and was using it to install a torch package then the app suddenly crashed. I closed the session and tried to start a new one, but I cant. It reports an Internal Sever Error, which said Disk quota exceed. (The error report is attached below). I doubt the python package installation produces too much temper files but when I checked the inode and space usage, it seems far below the limits. Could you give me any advice on how to figure the bug out, and how should I fix it? Thanks! name Hi name, Thank you for contacting us! You can use "myquota" command to check your disk space usage: $ myquota wei402 Type Location Size Limit Use Files Limit Use ============================================================================== home wei402 25.2GB 25.0GB 101% - - - scratch bell 4KB 200.0TB 0.00% 0k 2,000k 0.00% Your home directory is full. You can use "ncdu" command to check which parts taken the most space of your home folder and make some space. You can set the jupyter working directory to scratch folder to save some home space. Also, you can ask your PI to apply for the Data Depot storage: https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/knowledge/depot Each research group has 100 GB free space, it is also a long term storage and can be used to install kernels. For more details about different storage options, please see this training materials: https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/training/storage Best, name

I just checked your account, your HOME space is full, I think this is the reason you cannot login. @bell-fe06:~ $ myquota shu30 Type Location Size Limit Use Files Limit Use ============================================================================== home shu30 25.0GB 25.0GB 100% - - - scratch bell 167.3MB 200.0TB 0.00% 0k 2,000k 0.00% depot bingxin 47.1TB 50.0TB 95% - - - depot statdept 1016.0MB 100.0GB 1% - - - You can login Bell using 'ssh' at a terminal and clean up some space, then your ThinLinc will work. You can run 'ncdu' command at your HOME to see what eats your space. If you do not know how to use ssh login, feel free to check our user guide. https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/knowledge/bell/accounts/login Hope this helps, --- name, PhD Sr. Computational Scientist RCAC Research Computing Purdue University

title: Re: Scratch Filesystem Purge Policy Violation
customernote: Thank you for getting in touch, im reviewing these files and removing them. We are backing them up to fortress as well, and should soon be removing them._ From: Rosen Center for Advanced Computing Sent: Monday, July 10, 2023 3:11:58 PM To: name Cc: name Atallah name Subject: Scratch Filesystem Purge Policy Violation [RCAC]<https://www.rcac.purdue.edu> name, We are reaching out to you in regard to recently observed behavior on one or more community cluster scratch filesystems. We detected a rapid sweep of file access time updates consistent with blanket touching of all or part of your scratch directory in an attempt to circumvent purging. This is a clear and obvious violation of our acceptable use policy. The scratch filesystems are for limited-duration, high-performance storage of data for running jobs or workflows and are explicitly not intended to be used as a long-term storage. Doing so, or engaging in measures to circumvent purging, adversely affects all users of the system and our ability to provide such liberal quotas. Please review the scratch purge<https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/policies/scratchpurge> and resource usage<https://www.rcac.purdue.edu/policies/resourceuse> policies. Immediately cease this behavior and clear any unused data where possible. If necessary, consult our user guides and training material on archiving data and job outputs to the tape archive (Fortress). If these files must be available in perpetuity on a mounted filesystem, capacity on Data Depot is available for purchase. Staff are available to consult with you on data storage best practices and whatever challenges you might be facing. Regards, RCAC Staff If you have any questions about this email please contact . 2023 RCAC<https://www.rcac.purdue.edu>, a division of Purdue IT<https://www.itap.purdue.edu>. All rights reserved. Hello name, I'm closing the ticket. Let us know if you need any help with data management in the future. Cheers, name Lead Research Data Scientist Rosen Center for Advanced Computing Need additional help? Meet us on Mon-Thu 2-3 pm for informal coffee: http://www.rcac.purdue.edu/coffee

This queue utilizes idle cores from other queues. You can use this queue to run jobs of up to 4 hours. Wait times in standby will vary wildly (minutes to days) depending on cluster utilization and how many nodes your jobs request. Scratch Space Scratch space is available for storing large input and output data during computations. This space offers both a much larger quota and better performance than your home directory. Archival Space Long-term archival space is also offered via the Fortress HPSS Archival system. title: Negishi CPU allocation
customernote: [Some people who received this message don't often get email from . Learn why this is important at https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification ] Hi: I am submitting matlab jobs to Negishi. There is only one task per job, so there should be 1 CPU allocated, but it us allocating 13 CPUs for each job. My submit script is below. How can I force 1 CPU per job? Thanks name #!/bin/sh -l # FILENAME: myjob.sub #SBATCH --mem=24G # total memory per node #SBATCH --ntasks=1 #SBATCH --cpus-per-task=1 echo "myTrip.sub" hostname module load matlab/R2022a #cd $PBS_O_WORKDIR unset DISPLAY # -nodisplay: run MATLAB in text mode; X11 server not needed # -singleCompThread: turn off implicit parallelism # -r: read MATLAB program; use MATLAB JIT Accelerator matlab -nodisplay -singleCompThread -r popaeTrip Hi name, The "#SBATCH --ntasks=1" will request only 1 core for your job. But since you asked for 24 GB memory and there is only <= 2GB memory available on each core, so order to give you 24 GB memory, 13 cores are involved. Please check your matlab output and see if only 1 core is used for calculation and the rest are only used to provide enough memory. Also, you can test if 2 GB memory is enough for your calculation. If so, you can delete the memory command and the slrum job scheduler will only give you 1 core. Best, name  Hi: Thanks. That partly explains it. But does Negishi have less memory per CPU than Halstead? name On 7/11/23 11:54 AM, Purdue Customer Support wrote: > [Duplicate message snipped]  Hi name, I cannot remember the system architecture of Halstead, but usually each node will only mount 2 GB memory and the node name will use a small amount of memory, so the actual memory you can get from a node will be slightly less than 2 GB. Best, name

In fact, they are missing all of the following hostnames (some certainly dont matter): 128.211.133.138 ps.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 128.211.133.139 vendorbastion.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 128.211.133.159 z000.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.18.67.19 mgmttemp.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.18.67.20 mgmt.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.18.67.23 xcat01.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.18.67.25 adm01.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.18.67.29 kvm01.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.18.67.30 grafana.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.18.67.32 auth.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.18.67.33 xdmod.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.18.92.144 flash11.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.18.92.204 disk04.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.18.92.205 disk05.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.18.92.206 disk06.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.18.92.207 disk07.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.18.95.140 login00-ib0.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.18.95.141 login01-ib0.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.18.95.142 login02-ib0.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.18.95.143 login03-ib0.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.18.95.144 login04-ib0.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.18.95.145 login05-ib0.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.18.95.146 login06-ib0.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.18.95.147 login07-ib0.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.18.95.228 kvm-ib0.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.21.168.10 cloud00.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.21.168.11 cloud01.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.21.168.12 cloud02.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.21.168.13 cloud03.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.21.168.14 cloud04.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.21.168.15 cloud05.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.21.168.16 cloud06.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.21.168.17 cloud07.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.21.168.30 rancher00.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.21.168.31 rancher01.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.21.168.32 rancher02.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.21.168.33 kube00.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.21.168.34 kube01.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.21.168.35 kube02.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.21.168.40 cloudgpu00.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 172.21.168.9 cloudkvm.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu 2: login07.anvil consistently has one forth to one fifth the number of GPFS network connections than the other front-ends. I checked dozens of times over the last 4 days and though it fluctuates, it always looks something like this: (sanvil is just a shell script to ssh to all front-ends): outlier ~ $ sanvil "netstat -a -W | grep gpfs | awk '{print \$5}' | sed -e 's/:.*$//' | sort | uniq | wc" login00 --------------------------------- 979 979 26508 login01 --------------------------------- 1014 1014 27453 login02 --------------------------------- 1020 1020 27615 login03 --------------------------------- 1013 1013 27426 login04 --------------------------------- 1005 1005 27210 login05 --------------------------------- 1016 1016 27507 login06 --------------------------------- 1011 1011 27372 login07 --------------------------------- 214 214 5853 3: login07 is not registered as one of the round-name DNS values for http://anvil.rcac.purdue.edu, but it is actively used by ThinLinc and OnDemand. login00.anvil ~ $ host anvil http://anvil.rcac.purdue.edu has address 128.211.133.143 http://anvil.rcac.purdue.edu has address 128.211.133.145 http://anvil.rcac.purdue.edu has address 128.211.133.146 http://anvil.rcac.purdue.edu has address 128.211.133.144 http://anvil.rcac.purdue.edu has address 128.211.133.141 http://anvil.rcac.purdue.edu has address 128.211.133.142 http://anvil.rcac.purdue.edu has address 128.211.133.140 login00.anvil ~ $ host login07.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu login07.anvil.rcac.purdue.edu has address 128.211.133.147 4: According to splunk, Zabbix looks broken/unstable on disk*.anvil and flash*.anvil and seems to be constantly restarting. 5: When GPFS is acting up, some file creates from some front-ends will take extraordinarily long (like a full second or more) within some directories in /anvil/projects, but not in others. Im fortunately part of two different Anvil projects (tra220018 and cis220051) thus I have to areas I can check simultaneously. For example, there will be times where on login00, creates in /anvil/projects/tra220018 will take 1 second, but they will be instant in /anvil/projects/tdm or vice versa. During this same time, creates on login01 will be fine on both, but login02 could be slow in /anvil/projects/tdm and fast in /anvil/projects/tra220018. My simple loop to test is one of these (note I use the very fast > to create files rather than using the Trojaned and slower /usr/local/bin/touch) sanvil "cd /anvil/projects/tdm/corporate/test && (rm -f {1..10}; time (for i in {1..10}; do echo $i > $i; done))" sanvil "cd /anvil/projects/x-tra220018/2023/dgc && (rm -f {1..10}; time (for i in {1..10}; do echo $i > $i; done))" After things were resolved after the major Anvil downtime a couple of weeks ago, both of the above returned immediately with no slow creates. Immediately after the login01 reboot a few days ago I noticed the file creates started taking a long time again. I cant say if it was causal, but it was certainly correlated. 6: There are currently hundreds of jobs in device wait across the various front-ends. The load is artificially over 100 on some of them: outlier ~ $ sanvil uptime login00 --------------------------------- 10:03:47 up 7 days, 17:41, 9 users, load average: 71.03, 70.48, 69.53 login01 --------------------------------- 10:03:47 up 3 days, 17:06, 10 users, load average: 87.28, 87.56, 87.43 login02 --------------------------------- 10:03:47 up 12 days, 14:26, 18 users, load average: 108.04, 108.18, 107.76 login03 --------------------------------- 10:03:47 up 12 days, 14:26, 11 users, load average: 88.85, 88.23, 87.58 login04 --------------------------------- 10:03:48 up 12 days, 9:23, 14 users, load average: 83.00, 83.01, 82.76 login05 --------------------------------- 10:03:48 up 12 days, 9:23, 13 users, load average: 74.45, 74.56, 74.10 login06 --------------------------------- 10:03:48 up 12 days, 9:23, 13 users, load average: 104.14, 104.01, 103.59 login07 --------------------------------- 10:03:48 up 12 days, 9:23, 9 users, load average: 24.02, 24.01, 24.00 Regards, Doug" Thanks, name, Ph.D. Senior Computational Scientist ITaP Research Computing Purdue University Moving to new ticket system, Team Dynamix (TDX)
